skill.name: dispatching-parallel-agents
skill.description: Dispatch multiple Claude agents to work on independent problems concurrently, enabling parallel investigation and resolution of unrelated issues.
skill.summary: Efficiently parallelize debugging by dispatching one Claude agent per independent problem domain
skill.author: Cygnusfear

security_audit.summary: This skill is purely educational documentation with no executable code or security risks. All 21 static findings are false positives from pattern matching on documentation content and JSON metadata. The skill contains no network calls, filesystem operations, command execution, or malicious patterns.

content.user_title: Dispatch Parallel Agents for Faster Debugging
content.value_statement: When multiple independent bugs occur, sequential debugging wastes time. This skill teaches you to dispatch multiple Claude agents in parallel, each focused on one problem domain, dramatically reducing resolution time.
actual_capabilities: Teaches pattern for dispatching multiple Claude agents to work on independent problems concurrently
Provides decision framework for identifying when parallel agent dispatch is appropriate
Includes structured agent prompt templates for focused, self-contained investigation tasks
Offers real-world examples from debugging sessions with 3-6 concurrent agents
Explains integration and conflict resolution strategies when agents complete their work
limitations: Requires problems to be truly independent with no shared state or sequential dependencies
Not suitable for exploratory debugging where the problem scope is unknown
Effectiveness depends on ability to correctly identify independent problem domains
Does not provide automation or tooling, only methodology and best practices

use_cases.title: Parallel Test Failure Resolution
use_cases.description: When test suite has failures across multiple unrelated test files, dispatch one agent per test file to investigate and fix failures concurrently, reducing debugging time from sequential to parallel.

use_cases.title: Multi-Subsystem Bug Fixing
use_cases.description: When different subsystems have independent bugs after refactoring, create focused agents for each subsystem to work in parallel without interfering with each other.

use_cases.title: Concurrent Code Review Actions
use_cases.description: When code review reveals multiple independent issues in different parts of codebase, dispatch parallel agents to address each concern separately and efficiently.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Parallel Test Fix
prompt_templates.prompt: I have 3 test files failing independently. Dispatch 3 agents to fix tests/auth.test.ts, tests/api.test.ts, and tests/utils.test.ts in parallel.
prompt_templates.scenario: Multiple test files failing with unrelated root causes

prompt_templates.title: Subsystem-Specific Debugging
prompt_templates.prompt: After refactoring, authentication module and payment module both have bugs. Create one agent to investigate auth issues and another for payment issues. Have them work in parallel.
prompt_templates.scenario: Independent subsystems broken after major changes

prompt_templates.title: Focused Investigation with Context
prompt_templates.prompt: Fix the 3 failing tests in agent-tool-abort.test.ts. Tests are failing with timing issues. Read test file, identify root cause, fix by replacing timeouts with event-based waiting. Return summary of findings and changes.
prompt_templates.scenario: Specific test file needs focused debugging with constraints

prompt_templates.title: Complex Multi-Domain Dispatch
prompt_templates.prompt: We have 6 failures across 3 files: agent-tool-abort.test.ts has timing issues, batch-completion-behavior.test.ts has execution bugs, tool-approval-race-conditions.test.ts has race conditions. Dispatch 3 agents, one per file, to investigate and fix independently.
prompt_templates.scenario: Large-scale debugging with multiple independent problem domains

output_examples.input: Dispatch agents to fix 3 test files in parallel
output_examples.output: Agent 1 dispatched for tests/auth.test.ts. Agent 2 dispatched for tests/api.test.ts. Agent 3 dispatched for tests/utils.test.ts. All agents working concurrently.

output_examples.input: Review parallel agent results and integrate fixes
output: Agent 1 summary: Replaced timeouts with event-based waiting in auth tests
Agent 2 summary: Fixed event structure bug in API response handling
Agent 3 summary: Added async completion wait in utility functions
Integration check: No conflicts detected. All fixes are independent. Running full test suite.

best_practices: Ensure problems are truly independent before dispatching parallel agents - check for shared state or sequential dependencies
Provide each agent with focused scope, complete context, clear constraints, and specific output requirements
After agents complete, review all summaries, check for conflicts between changes, and run full test suite to verify integration
anti_patterns: Dispatching parallel agents for related failures where fixing one might resolve others - investigate together first
Creating agents with overly broad scope like fixing all tests - narrow focus prevents agents from getting lost
Skipping conflict review when integrating parallel agent changes - agents can unknowingly edit the same code or create incompatible fixes

faq.question: How do I know if problems are independent enough for parallel agents?
faq.answer: Problems are independent if each can be understood and fixed without context from others, they do not share state, and fixing one does not affect the others. Test failures in different files are usually independent.

faq.question: What happens if parallel agents edit the same files?
faq.answer: Review agent summaries after completion to identify conflicts. If agents edited same code sections, manually integrate changes or re-run one agent with context from the other. This is rare with proper problem domain identification.

faq.question: How many agents can I dispatch in parallel?
faq.answer: Dispatch one agent per independent problem domain. Typical range is 2 to 6 agents. More agents provide diminishing returns if problems are not truly independent or if review time exceeds parallel execution benefits.

faq.question: Should I use this for exploratory debugging?
faq.answer: No. Parallel dispatch requires knowing what is broken and that problems are independent. For exploratory debugging where problem scope is unknown, use single agent investigation first to map out issues.

faq.question: How detailed should agent prompts be?
faq.answer: Provide focused scope, complete context including error messages, clear constraints on what not to change, and specific output format. Good prompts are self-contained so agents need no additional information.

faq.question: What if one agent fails to complete its task?
faq.answer: Review the agent summary to understand what blocked it. You can dispatch a new agent with refined instructions, or handle that problem domain manually after integrating fixes from successful agents.
